verses.text: For \add the ungodly\add* said, reasoning with themselves, \add but\add* not aright, Our life is short and tedious, and in the death of a man there is no remedy: neither was there any \add man\add* known to have returned from the grave.
For we are born at all adventure: and we shall be hereafter as though we had never been: for the breath in our nostrils \add is as\add* smoke, and a little spark in the moving of our heart:
which being extinguished, \add our\add* body shall be turned into ashes, and our spirit shall vanish as the soft air,

and our name shall be forgotten in time, and no \add man\add* shall have our works in remembrance, and our life shall pass away as the trace of a cloud, and shall be dispersed as a mist, that is driven \add away\add* with the beams of the sun, and overcome with the heat thereof.
For our time \add is\add* a \add very\add* shadow that passeth away; and after our end there is no returning: for it is fast sealed, so that no \add man\add* cometh again.
Come on therefore, let us enjoy the good \add things\add* that are present: and let us speedily use the creatures like as in youth.
Let us fill ourselves with costly wine and ointments: and let no flower of the spring pass by us:
let us crown ourselves with rosebuds, before \add they\add* be withered:
let none of us go without his part of our voluptuousness: let us leave tokens of \add our\add* joyfulness in every place: for this \add is\add* our portion, and our lot \add is\add* this.
Let us oppress the poor righteous \add man\add*, let us not spare the widow, nor reverence the ancient gray hairs of the aged.
Let our strength be the law of justice: for \add that which is\add* feeble is found \add to be\add* nothing worth.

Therefore let us lie in wait for the righteous; because he is not for our turn, and he is clean contrary to our doings: he upbraideth us with \add our\add* offending the law, and objecteth to our infamy the transgressings of our education.
He professeth to have the knowledge of God: and he calleth himself the child of the Lord.
He was made to reprove our thoughts.
He is grievous unto us even to behold: for his life \add is\add* not like other \add men\add*â€™s, his ways \add are\add* of another fashion.
We are esteemed of him as counterfeits: he abstaineth from our ways as from filthiness: he pronounceth the end of the just to be blessed, and maketh his boast that God \add is his\add* father.
Let us see if his words \add be\add* true: and let us prove what shall happen in the end of him.
For if the just \add man\add* be the son of God, he will help him, and deliver him from the hand of \add his\add* enemies.
Let us examine him with despitefulness and torture, that we may know his meekness, and prove his patience.
Let us condemn him with a shameful death: for by his own saying he shall be respected.
Such \add things\add* they did imagine, and were deceived: for their own wickedness hath blinded them.
As for the mysteries of God, they knew them not: neither hoped they for the wages of righteousness, nor discerned a reward for blameless souls.
For God created man to be immortal, and made him \add to be\add* an image of his own eternity.
Nevertheless through envy of the devil came death into the world: and they that do hold of his side do find it.
